content:
What house
gives no hostages, cannot be burned, and cannot be harried? (The fairy
stronghold [sídh] of brugh na Boinne.

Riddle: what is the creature that is of all countries, that
is loved by all the world, and that has no equal?

Riddle: the father not yet born, the son already at the top
of the house.

Riddle of the Sphinx: what is it that goes on four legs in
the morning, on two at midday, and on three in the evening.

(Man, who crawls as a
child, walks in middle life, and walks with a stick in old age.) **Aarne FFC
XXVII 3ff.; **Laistner Rätsel der Sphinx; Gascon: Bladé I 10 No. 1.; Greek:
Frazer Apollodorus I 349 n. 1 Köhler-Bolte I 115; Fb “menneske” II 578a.
child:
Riddle: two are better than three (two legs better than man
with staff in old age).

content: Riddle: what is whiter than a swan? An angel.
Riddle: what is dearer than gold? Mother love.
Riddle: bird without feathers flies on tree without leaves.
(Snow falls on bare tree.) **Aarne FFC XXVIII 1ff.

child: Riddle: how much does the moon weigh?

How much does the moon weigh? A pound, for it has four
quarters.
*Type 922; BP III 232; *Anderson FFC XLII 173; Köhler-Bolte I 458.

How much does the moon weigh? So and so much, and if you
don’t believe it go and weigh it yourself.
Riddle: how heavy is the earth?

How heavy is the earth? Take away all the stones and I will
weigh it.
Riddle: how much water is in the sea?

How much water is in the sea? Stop all the rivers and I
will measure it.

How much water is in the sea? So and so much, and if you
don‘t believe it, go measure it yourself.

How much water is in the sea? A tub-full if the tub is
large enough.
How many measures of water are in the river?

content:
Death sentence escaped by propounding riddle king (judge)
cannot solve *Type 927; *De Vries FFC LXXIII 314f.

; **F. J. Norton FL LIII
27--57; Köhler-Bolte I 46; Penzer I 51, 51n.; Malone PMLA XLIII 407; Icelandic:
Boberg; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 112 No. 927*A.
child: If he solves it he wins suit. India: Thompson-Balys.

content: Escape from devil by answering his riddles.

*Type 812; BP III 12ff.; Fb “spørgsmål” III 524b; Lithuanian: Balys Legends No. 754; Jamaica:
*Beckwith MAFLS XVII 275 No. 86.
child: Devil held off from person by answering his riddles.

St. Andrew the Bishop,
and the Devil. The Devil, in form of beautiful maiden visits a holy bishop. St.
Andrew appears as a pilgrim, answers the questions through which the devil
seeks to keep him at a distance and discomfits the devil. (Cf. †B302.22.3.)
Anderson FFC LXII 353; Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 45; Spanish Exempla:
Keller.
Child in cradle guesses devil’s riddle: all are saved.

(See also †H541.1.1,
†H543, †G681.) Child I 13ff., 484, II 495; Icelandic: *Boberg; India:
*Thompson-Balys.
Queen of Sheba propounds riddles to Solomon.
Riddles sent to Solomon by King Hiram.
Bridegroom propounds riddles at wedding feast.

content: Riddle propounded with penalty for failure.
child: Riddle propounded on pain of death.

(Cf. †H512.) *Type 922;
**Anderson FFC XLII 252; *BP III 230; *Oertel Studien zur vgl. Littgsch. VIII
121; Malone PMLA XLIII 398f.; Fb “bejler” IV
31b; English: Child V 493 “riddles”; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Sphinx propounds riddle on pain of death.

**Laistner Rätsel der
Sphinx; Fb “menneske” II 578a; Gascon: Bladé I
3 No. 1; Greek: Frazer Apollodorus I 349 n. 1; Persian: Carnoy 335; Hindu:
Penzer IX 143.
Riddle propounded on pain of loss of property.
Fine for failure to solve riddle.
Riddle propounded on pain of loss of official position.

content: Answers found in other world to riddles propounded on way.
Riddle: who first spun and when?
Riddle: what were the clothes of Adam and Eve?
Riddle: who, having neither father nor mother, are dead?
Riddle: who, having had father and mother, is not dead?

Riddle: who, having had father and mother, is not dead like
other mortals?

(Lot’s wife.) Chauvin V 195
No. 114; Scala Celi No. 821.
Riddle: who has had, here below, two names?
Riddle: why are there more women than men?

(Some women make women [i.e., weaklings] of their
husbands.) Chauvin V 38 No. 365.
Who is greater than God? Man‘s purpose.

Riddle: how much is a certain crucifix worth? Twenty-nine
pieces of silver.
Riddle: how much does the sun earn for his daily work?
child:
How much does the sun earn for his daily work? A day’s
wages.

content:
Riddle: how much is a golden plow (throne, crown, palace)
worth?
child:
How much is a golden plow (throne, crown, palace) worth? A
rain in May.

content: Riddle: how much is my beard (king‘s) worth?
*Type 875; De Vries FFC LXXIII 160; BP II 359.
child:
How much is king’s beard worth? The months July, August,
and September.

How much is king‘s beard worth? A May rain (three rains in
summer).
De Vries FFC LXXIII 161; Köhler-Bolte I 456.

content: Riddle: how much am I (the king) worth?
Anderson FFC XLII 194; cf. Aarne FFC XXIII 129.
child:
How much am I (the king) worth? Twenty-nine pieces of
silver, for Christ was sold for thirty.

content:
Riddle: what is swifter than a bird, the wind or lightning?
The eye.

From wooden spring iron bucket makes stones from which
water flows.

(Metal stick picks stone from
eye. If you rub lids with it, tears come.) Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas III
32, 297f., *Neuman.

What three not born of male and female ate and drank on
earth?

Riddle: the king is surrounded by his nobles; what is this
like?

(The idol Bel surrounded by the
priests of the god.) Chauvin VI 39 No. 207.

Riddle: what is that which has drunk water for its
sustenance and eaten after its death?
(Moses’s staff, which became a serpent.) Chauvin V 194 No. 114.
Riddle: what does the king of the world of the Devas do?
Punishes the bad people. India: Thompson-Balys.
Riddle: what did Christ do in his 30th year?

Answer: entered into his
thirty-first. (Cf. †H865.) Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Riddle: what was the walking tomb with the living tenant?

(Jonah and the whale.) Chauvin V 194 No. 114; Jewish:
*Neuman.
What is the tree that became flesh?
Riddle: what is the land that has seen the sun only once?

(The bottom of the Red Sea during the passage of the
Israelites.) Chauvin V 194 No. 114; Jewish: *Neuman.
child: What is the land that has seen the sun only once?

(The land on which the waters were gathered after the
creation.) Jewish: Neuman.
Man puts on shoes only when he wades river.

(He cannot see what he is walking on.) India:
Thompson-Balys.

(To protect self from falling branches and bird
droppings.) India: Thompson-Balys.
Man cuts hooks for the revenge of his father (Hamlet).

content:
Girls answer in single words, which, when arranged in
certain order, show that they accept. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Enigmatic statement made clear by experience.
child:
Girl compares her love for her father to salt. Experience teaches
him the value of salt. *Type 923; *BP III 305 n. 2, IV 407; *Hartland FLJ IV
309; *DeCock Studien en Essays 4f.; Cosquin Contes Indiens 103ff.; Köhler
Aufsätze 14; India: *Thompson-Balys. Cf. Shakespeare‘s King Lear.

Husband offended but later learns wife’s meaning. Type
923A.
Poison in nectar: wife who betrays husband to his enemies.
Nectar in poison: mistress who saves her lover.
Dogs in human shape: friends who seduce man‘s wife.
Donkey ruling a kingdom: king condemning man unjustly.

content:
Sounds very inhospitable but properly interpreted makes
guests welcome. India: Thompson-Balys.

child: Enigmatic statement: roof has no eaves.

(Else it would give the beggar shelter.) India:
Thompson-Balys.

Enigmatic statement: the tank (pond) does not belong to
you.

(Else you would have given the beggar
fish to eat.) India: Thompson-Balys.
Enigmatic statement: the flocks are only rocks and grass.

(Else you would have given the beggar milk and curds.)
India: Thompson-Balys.

content: Enigmatic counsels of relatives (other than father).
child:
Gray younger brother asks well-preserved older brother for
the secret of his good health. Answer: A measured mouth, a close purse, and a
knot on the trouser’s fly. Spanish: Childers.
Girl will not drink of water which had no father or mother
Enigmatic statements of a sham mad man (Hamlet).

Clever flatterer: Sir, you are a full moon, and my
sovereign is a new moon (the full moon will decline, but the new moon has but
started on its growth).

Man asked to kill thousands, press hundreds beneath his
arm, etc.

(To shave his head, put some
hairs under his arm, etc.) India: Thompson-Balys.

Enigmatic counsel: uproot old trees and plant new ones
(dismiss old governors and appoint new).

Give coals orange color, let glimmer of gold appear like
expanse of heaven, prepare two heads of darkness.
(Request for chickens for breakfast.) Jewish: Neuman.

content: Riddle: how many leaves are on the tree?
Anderson FFC XLII 175; West Indies: Flowers 459.
child:
How many leaves are on the tree? As many as there are stems
for.

How many leaves are on the tree? So and so many; and if you
don’t believe it, go count them.

How many leaves are on the tree? Counterquestion: how many
stars in the sky?

content: Riddle: how many days have passed since the time of Adam?
child:
How many days have passed since the time of Adam? The seven
days of the week.

When were you born? Its beginning is like its end, its top
like its bottom (1691).

content: Riddle: how many seconds in eternity?
child:
How many seconds in eternity? A bird carries a grain of
sand from a mountain each century; when the whole mountain is gone, the first
second of eternity has passed.

content: Riddle: how many stars in the heavens?

*Type 922; BP III 231; Anderson FFC XLII 162ff.; Spanish:
Boggs FFC XC 116 No. 970.
child:
How many stars in the heavens? As many as the grains of
sand; if you don’t believe it, count them yourself.

How many stars in the heaven? Two million; if you don‘t
believe it, count them yourself.

How many stars in the heavens? As many as the hairs in the
head; if you don’t believe it, count them yourself.

How many stars in the heavens? As many as the hairs in the
goatskin (on a donkey).

How many stars in the heavens? As many as the points on
paper; if you don‘t believe it, count them yourself.

content: Riddle: how many hairs are in the head?
child:
How many hairs are there in the head? As many as are in the
tail of my ass; if you don‘t believe it we will keep pulling out one hair from
your beard and one from his tail.

content: Riddle: two legs, three legs, four legs.

child:
What does God do? He brings low the proud and exalts the
lowly

(said by shepherd masking as bishop to king, who has exchanged places with
him). (Cf. †H562.) Anderson FFC XLII 207.

What does God do? God is astonished that I sit on a horse
and the king on an ass

content:
Relationship riddles arising from unusual marriages of
relatives.
Riddle: what house was full of dead?

(Philistines in the building demolished by Samson.)
Jewish: Neuman.
Riddle: seven tongues in a head.

(A horse‘s head in which a bird’s nest is found with
seven birds in it.) *Type 927; Köhler-Bolte I 46; *Fb “hestehoved”.

I am unborn; my horse is unborn; I carry my mother on my hands. (A boy who has
been taken from his dead mother‘s body digs up the body of his mother and makes
gloves of her skin. He rides on a colt which has been taken from a dead mare’s
body.) *Type 851; BP I 196; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 112 No. 927*B; Africa
(Swahili): Werner African 356.
Riddle: a fish was my father; a man was my mother.

(Man eats magic fish and becomes pregnant; a girl is taken
from his knee.) *Type 705; *Fb “fisk” I 297; Norse: Christiansen Norske Eventyr
96.

*Anderson FFC XLII 219ff.; Fb “konge” II 264b, “gjætte” I 452a, “liv” II 438b; Irish myth: Cross; India:
Thompson-Balys.
child:
“That I am the priest.” So answers youth masking as priest. *Type 922; BP III
214ff.; **Anderson FFC XLII 219ff.; India: *Thompson-Balys.

content:
Questioner has branch of blackthorn laden with berries
under her cloak. Irish myth: Cross.

Guessing: whether more of a certain stone is above or below
ground.

A test set by heathen king for a
saint. Irish myth: Cross.

child: Test: guessing origin of certain skin.
Test: guessing nature of certain skin--louse-skin.

Louse (flea) is fattened
and its skin made into coat (drum, etc.) *Type 621; BP III 484; *Taylor MPh XV
224 n. 2; Breton: Sébillot Incidents s.v. “bète”; Italian: Basile Pentamerone I No. 5; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Filipino: Fansler MAFLS XII 114.
Test: guessing nature of certain skin--wolf-skin.
Test: guessing origin of animal lungs.

Lungs of fattened lizard are further inflated. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.
Test: guessing nature of certain plant.

Plant came from scrapings of princesses‘ bodies. India:
Thompson-Balys.
Test: identifying what type of rice is in sack.

content: Test: guessing nature of devil’s possessions.
child: Test: guessing nature of devil‘s horse.
Test: guessing nature of devil’s cloth.
Test: guessing nature of devil‘s gold cup.
Answer: cup of pitch. *Type 812; BP III 12ff.
Test: guessing nature of devil’s roast meat.
Test: guessing nature of devil‘s spoon.
Test: guessing nature of devil’s wine glass.
Test: guessing nature of devil’s plate.
Test: guessing nature of devil‘s purse.

content: Guessing sex of unborn child (or animal).
child: Test: to prophesy offspring of cow and mare.

content:
Riddling remarks of traveling companion interpreted by girl
(man) at end of journey.

De Vries FFC LXXIII 43ff.; *Wesselski Märchen 197 No. 7; India:
Thompson-Balys.
child: Man helps traveler and makes riddling remarks.

Gives him food, shares
his coat in rain, and carries him over stream. Reproaches him with traveling
without mother, house, or bridge (nourishment, shelter, or horse).
*Köhler-Bolte I 197f.; Nouvelles de Sens No. 3.

Traveler says he is going to the city to see what has
become of the seed he sowed in the street.

(What has become of the girl he left in the
city to await his return.) Köhler-Bolte I 197; Nouvelles de Sens No. 3.

Traveler says he is going to seek a hind that he saw in the
woods ten years before.

Traveler says he must look after his net to see if it has
taken fish.

(He has left his lady seven
years before with a pledge of faithfulness. Net has taken fish--lady has had
lovers.) English: Child I 191 n.

One traveler to another: Let us carry each other and
shorten the way.

(Let us tell tales and amuse ourselves on the way.) *Wesselski
Märchen 197 No. 7; Nouvelles de Sens Nos. 3, 8; India: *Thompson-Balys.

One traveler to another: That field (uncut) is already
harvested.

(Belongs to spendthrift who has already spent the money.) Wesselski Märchen 197
No. 7.

One traveler to another (as they see corpse borne by): He
is not entirely dead.
(Has left good property.) Wesselski Märchen 197 No. 7.

One traveler to another (when asked how he crossed an
unbridged stream): I cross on an ashen bridge.

(Found a ford with an
ashen staff.) Wesselski Märchen 197 No. 7; Nouvelles de Sens No. 8.
One traveler to another: Is this cup valuable or not?
(Is your daughter married or not?) India: Thompson-Balys.

Boy says that travelers should catch the mares (walking
sticks that are in the jungle).

content: King gives enigmatic order to minister.
child:
Enigmatic letter of king must be explained on pain of
death.

King: Show me a ruby eight for a pice, nectar eight for a
pice, and a faithless creature worth one-eighth of a pice.

Minister: The lamp sells at eight for a pice and gives
more light than any ruby; the water is the real nectar; and the dog is
worthless and faithless lover because he follows anyone who feeds him. India:
Thompson-Balys.

content: Enigmatic conversation of king and peasant.
child:
(Focus.) King: What do you do with the four coins you earn?
Peasant: First I eat (feed self); second I put out at interest (give my
children); third I give back (pay debts); fourth I throw away (give my wife.)
Köhler-Bolte Zs. f. Vksk. VI 161 (to Gonzenbach No. 50); BP IV 137; Oesterley
No. 57; cf. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 8; Anderson FFC XLII 356 n. 1.--Lithuanian:
Balys Index No. 921A*; Russian: Andrejev No. 921 I*; Italian Novella: Rotunda;
India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Swahili): Steere 295.

King: Why did you not do it (marry so that sons could help
you)? Peasant: I did, but it was not God’s will (I married three times but it
was not God‘s will

to give me sons).
India: Thompson-Balys.

content:
Riddling answers betray theft or adultery *BP I 198, II
361f.

;
Köhler-Bolte Zs. f. Vksk. VI 59 (to Gonzenbach No. 1); *Wesselski Märchen 197.
child: The full moon and the thirtieth of the month.

Prince sends servant to clever girl with a round tart,
thirty cakes, and a capon, and asks her if it is full moon and the thirtieth of
the month and if the cock has crowed in the evening. She replies that it is not
full moon, that it is the fifteenth of the month, and that the capon has gone to
the mill; but that the prince should spare the pheasant for the partridge’s sake. She thus shows
him that the servant has stolen half the tart, half of the cakes, and the
capon. *BP II 361; Köhler Zs. f. Vksk. VI 59; Arab: Azov 401f.; Africa (Sahel):
Frobenius Atlantis VI 79--86.

(Cf. †T411.) Woman,
recognizing cleric as her son by her father (Fiachna), gives him a drink of
milk and says, “I give drink to my brother; he
is Fiachna‘s son, he is Fiachna’s grandson; his mother is Fiachna‘s daughter.”
The son’s reply shows that he understands the situation. Irish myth: *Cross.

Woman‘s question to her husband disguised as woman, how
many men she had in one night.

This is
properly understood as, how many helpers he had, and answered by lifting ten
fingers. Icelandic: Boberg.

content: Clever youth (maiden) answers king’s inquiry in riddles.
child:
King: What do you see? Youth: One and a half men and a
horse‘s head.

King: Are you alone at home? Youth: Not now; I see the half
of two quadrupeds.

(Two legs of the king and the forefeet of his horse.)
*Köhler-Bolte I 84, 87.

King: What is your father doing? Youth: He is in the
vineyard and is doing good and bad.

(He prunes vines and sometimes cuts good and sometimes lets bad
ones stay.) *Köhler-Bolte I 84, 87.

King: What is your father doing? Youth: Makes an evil
greater.

(Closes up a path; this causes
another to be opened.) *De Vries FFC LXXIII 116ff.

King: What is your father doing? Youth: Makes many out of
few.

King: What is your father doing? Youth: Makes better from
good.

King: What is your father doing? Youth: Cuts wood which was
burnt last year.

(To pay old debts.) *De
Vries FFC LXXIII 116ff.

King: What is your father doing? Youth: He fences thorns
with thorns.

(Eggplant garden fenced with
thorns.) India: Thompson-Balys.

King: What is your brother doing? Youth: He hunts; he
throws away what he catches and what he does not catch he carries with him.

King: What is your brother doing? Youth: He runs back and
forth.

King: What is your brother doing? Youth: He sits between
heaven and earth.

King: What is your mother doing? Youth: She does for
another what the latter cannot do for her.
(Lays out a corpse.) *De Vries FFC LXXIII 124ff.

King: What is your mother doing? Youth: She shows the light
of the world to one who has not yet seen it.
(Assists at a birth.) De Vries FFC LXXIII 124ff.

King: What is your mother doing? Youth: She is baking the
bread we ate last week.

(To pay back borrowed bread.) (Cf. †H583.2.4.) *De Vries FFC
LXXIII 124ff.; Köhler-Bolte I 85, 87.

King: What is your mother doing? Youth: She cuts off the
heads of the well to cure the sick.
(Kills chickens to feed her sick mother.) Köhler-Bolte I 85, 87.

King: What is your mother doing? Youth: She drives away the
hungry and compels the filled to eat.

(Drives away the hungry hens and stuffs the geese.) Köhler-Bolte
I 85, 87.

King: What are your mother and father doing? Girl: Mother
is separating earth (being a midwife), and father is mixing earth (at a
funeral).

King: What is your mother doing? Girl: She has gone to turn
one into two (to split peas).

King: What is your sister doing? Youth: She is mourning
last year‘s laughter.

(Nurses child, the
fruit of last year’s love affair.) *De Vries FFC LXXIII 133ff.

King: What are you doing? Youth: I boil those which come
and go.

(Beans which keep rising and
falling in water.) *Types 875, 921; De Vries FFC LXXIII 115.

King: Where shall I tie my horse? Maiden: Between summer
and winter.

(Between wagon and sleigh.) De
Vries FFC LXXIII 254.
Maiden (to king): The house has neither eyes nor ears.

(No child at window nor dog in yard to announce king‘s
approach: he therefore finds her not dressed to receive him.) De Vries FFC
LXXIII 252.
Maiden (to king): Shall I feed you with loss or gain.

(A slaughtered hen or milk.) De Vries FFC LXXIII 254;
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1465*; Rumanian: Schullerus FFC LXXVIII No. 877*.

Girl to king: Should it (the flood) come I shall not come;
should it not come, I shall come.
Girl given enigmatic commands must do the opposite.

content: Three young men arrested tell who they are.
child:
Arrested man tells who he is: before his father the great
incline the head and give blood and money (barber).

Arrested man tells who he is: the hospitable fire of his
father is sought (bean merchant).

Arrested man tells who he is: father throws himself into
the ranks and holds them (weaver).

Arrested farmer tells who he is: one son is thief (priest),
second beggar (teacher), and third murderer (doctor).

content:
Taken literally bring trouble, but when properly
interpreted are valuable. Icelandic: Hervarar saga 36--39, 116--18, *Boberg;
India: Thompson-Balys, (Kashmir): Knowles 243; Indonesia: De Vries’s list No.
232; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 256 No. 200.
child:
Father-in-law gives daughter-in-law enigmatic permission to
go home.

Father’s counsel: walk not in sunshine from your house to
your shop.

(Attend to business, rising
early and retiring late.) India: Thompson-Balys.
Father‘s counsel: let pilav be your daily food.
Father’s counsel: marry a new wife every week.
(Do not see your wife too much.) India: Thompson-Balys.

Father‘s counsel: on wishing to drink wine go to the vat
and drink it.

(Stench in vat so great that
desire for wine is turned to loathing.) India: *Thompson-Balys.

Father’s counsel: if you want to gamble, then gamble with
experienced gamblers.

(If you see how
wretched professional gamblers are you will not want to gamble.) *Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 376; India: Thompson-Balys.

Father‘s counsel: dress up the trunks of trees, cover the
road.

(Plant the road with fruit trees and
betel between the trees.) India: *Thompson-Balys; Batak: Voorhoeve 164f. No.
169.
Father’s counsel: find treasure within a foot of the ground.

(Sons dig everywhere and thus loosen soil of vineyard,
which becomes fruitful.) Wienert FFC LVI 82 (ET 490), 126 (ST 346); Halm Aesop
No. 98; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 914*; India: Thompson-Balys.

Three empty and one full (3 sons and father). Full one can
fill the three empty but the three when full cannot fill the one when empty
(sons when scattered will not support the father). India: Thompson-Balys.
Father’s counsel: dam up the outlets.

(Keep expenditures down--not outlets of rice-field as
son-in-law thinks). India: *Thompson-Balys.

Father‘s counsel: don’t stay too late with a concubine, nor
tell her any secret.

(Working diligently, your bread will be as sweet as
honey.) Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 915A*.

(Start your work the earliest, so that not you but others may greet you.)
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 915A*.

(Walk the fields bare-footed, wearing your shoes only when nearing the town.)
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 915A*.

“Take people by the locks” (use your influence to make
people subservient to you).

“If you have to go to a prostitute, go early in the
morning.”
“When you go to the bazar, eat your morning meal first.”

“A father should always check and never forgive; a mother
should always forgive and never check.”
Enigmatic advice: take only salt and water as food.

content:
Irish
myth: Cross; Jewish: *Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys, Penzer VI 74 n.
child: Test of wisdom: wise man sends ruler magic gems.

Ruler admires their beauty but neglects to inquire of
their virtues. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Wise man answers questions of many with single speech.
Sons tested for wisdom; given same amount of money.
What will they do with it? India: Thompson-Balys.

What animal which lives in sea-water will drown if taken
out of it?

What animal which lives in fire will burn if taken out of
it?
What animal has one voice living and seven voices dead?

(Ibis, from whose carcass musical instruments are made.)
Jewish: Neuman.
Riddle: what animal is good living but not dead?
Riddle: what animal is good dead but not living?
Riddle: what animal is good living and dead?
Riddle: what animal is not good living or dead?

content:
Riddle: who of fourfold beard is he, of azure foot and neck
so ruddy? Arrow.
Riddle: bill white, horns on feet, knob on head (cock).

child: What is most beautiful? The spring.
What is deepest? The heart of man.
De Vries FFC LXXIII 92; BP II 358.
What is highest? Sun, moon, and stars.
What is longest? The way through the world.

content: Riddle: what is the most beloved?

Test of resourcefulness: carrying wolf, goat, and cabbage
across stream.

Man is to set across a
stream, in a boat that will hold himself and only one other object, a wolf, a
goat, and a cabbage. He must do this so that the wolf doesn‘t eat the goat, nor
the goat the cabbage. Two solutions: (1) (a) take goat over, (b) take wolf over
and goat back, (c) take cabbage over, (d) take goat over; (2) (a) take goat over,
(b) take cabbage over and goat back, (c) take wolf over, (d) take goat over.
*Bolte Zs. f. Vksk. XXXIII--XXXIV 38; Fb “ulv” III 970a, “kål” II 354b.

King and peasant: the plucked fowl.

The king gives riddling questions to a peasant, who always

interpret them. They pay the peasant good money for the answers. Peasant tells

Thompson-Balys.

How far is it from one end of the earth to the other? A
day’s journey, since the sun makes it daily.

waist-deep, neck-deep; and beyond that over the head.

you don’t believe it, measure it yourself.

How far is it from earth to heaven? Not far; when it

How far from earth to heaven? The devil knows for he has

How wide is heaven? So and so wide, and if you do not

Girls answer in single words, which, when arranged in

child:

sand from a mountain each century; when the whole mountain is gone, the first

Enigmatic letter of king must be explained on pain of

King: Show me a ruby eight for a pice, nectar eight for a
pice, and a faithless creature worth one-eighth of a pice.

more light than any ruby; the water is the real nectar; and the dog is
worthless and faithless lover because he follows anyone who feeds him. India:
Thompson-Balys.

content: Enigmatic conversation of king and peasant.
child:
(Focus.) King: What do you do with the four coins you earn?
Peasant: First I eat (feed self); second I put out at interest (give my
children); third I give back (pay debts); fourth I throw away (give my wife.)
Köhler-Bolte Zs. f. Vksk. VI 161 (to Gonzenbach No. 50); BP IV 137; Oesterley

India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Swahili): Steere 295.

King: Why did you not do it (marry so that sons could help
you)? Peasant: I did, but it was not God’s will (I married three times but it
was not God‘s will

to give me sons).
India: Thompson-Balys.

content:
Riddling answers betray theft or adultery *BP I 198, II
361f.

;
Köhler-Bolte Zs. f. Vksk. VI 59 (to Gonzenbach No. 1); *Wesselski Märchen 197.
child: The full moon and the thirtieth of the month.

Prince sends servant to clever girl with a round tart,
thirty cakes, and a capon, and asks her if it is full moon and the thirtieth of
the month and if the cock has crowed in the evening. She replies that it is not
full moon, that it is the fifteenth of the month, and that the capon has gone to
the mill; but that the prince should spare the pheasant for the partridge’s sake. She thus shows
him that the servant has stolen half the tart, half of the cakes, and the
capon. *BP II 361; Köhler Zs. f. Vksk. VI 59; Arab: Azov 401f.; Africa (Sahel):
Frobenius Atlantis VI 79--86.

(Cf. †T411.) Woman,
recognizing cleric as her son by her father (Fiachna), gives him a drink of
milk and says, “I give drink to my brother; he
is Fiachna‘s son, he is Fiachna’s grandson; his mother is Fiachna‘s daughter.”
The son’s reply shows that he understands the situation. Irish myth: *Cross.

Woman‘s question to her husband disguised as woman, how
many men she had in one night.

This is
properly understood as, how many helpers he had, and answered by lifting ten
fingers. Icelandic: Boberg.

content: Clever youth (maiden) answers king’s inquiry in riddles.
child:
King: What do you see? Youth: One and a half men and a
horse‘s head.

King: Are you alone at home? Youth: Not now; I see the half
of two quadrupeds.

(Two legs of the king and the forefeet of his horse.)
*Köhler-Bolte I 84, 87.

King: What is your father doing? Youth: He is in the
vineyard and is doing good and bad.

(He prunes vines and sometimes cuts good and sometimes lets bad
ones stay.) *Köhler-Bolte I 84, 87.

King: What is your father doing? Youth: Makes an evil
greater.

(Closes up a path; this causes
another to be opened.) *De Vries FFC LXXIII 116ff.

King: What is your father doing? Youth: Makes many out of
few.

King: What is your father doing? Youth: Makes better from
good.

King: What is your father doing? Youth: Cuts wood which was
burnt last year.

(To pay old debts.) *De
Vries FFC LXXIII 116ff.

King: What is your father doing? Youth: He fences thorns
with thorns.

(Eggplant garden fenced with
thorns.) India: Thompson-Balys.

King: What is your brother doing? Youth: He hunts; he
throws away what he catches and what he does not catch he carries with him.

King: What is your brother doing? Youth: He runs back and
forth.

King: What is your brother doing? Youth: He sits between
heaven and earth.

King: What is your mother doing? Youth: She does for
another what the latter cannot do for her.
(Lays out a corpse.) *De Vries FFC LXXIII 124ff.

King: What is your mother doing? Youth: She shows the light
of the world to one who has not yet seen it.
(Assists at a birth.) De Vries FFC LXXIII 124ff.

bread we ate last week.

(To pay back borrowed bread.) (Cf. †H583.2.4.) *De Vries FFC
LXXIII 124ff.; Köhler-Bolte I 85, 87.

King: What is your mother doing? Youth: She cuts off the
heads of the well to cure the sick.
(Kills chickens to feed her sick mother.) Köhler-Bolte I 85, 87.

King: What is your mother doing? Youth: She drives away the
hungry and compels the filled to eat.

(Drives away the hungry hens and stuffs the geese.) Köhler-Bolte
I 85, 87.

King: What are your mother and father doing? Girl: Mother
is separating earth (being a midwife), and father is mixing earth (at a
funeral).

King: What is your mother doing? Girl: She has gone to turn
one into two (to split peas).

King: What is your sister doing? Youth: She is mourning
last year‘s laughter.

(Nurses child, the
fruit of last year’s love affair.) *De Vries FFC LXXIII 133ff.

King: What are you doing? Youth: I boil those which come
and go.

(Beans which keep rising and
falling in water.) *Types 875, 921; De Vries FFC LXXIII 115.

and winter.

(Between wagon and sleigh.) De
Vries FFC LXXIII 254.

approach: he therefore finds her not dressed to receive him.) De Vries FFC

(A slaughtered hen or milk.) De Vries FFC LXXIII 254;

go home.

your shop.

early and retiring late.) India: Thompson-Balys.

child: Clever peasant girl asked riddles by king.

*Type 875; **De Vries
FFC LXXIII 52ff.; *Hdwb. d. Märchens I 195a; India: *Thompson-Balys; Japanese:

Clever peasant wife asks king riddles.

Conflict between peasant and nobleman decided so that each
must answer riddles: peasant’s daughter solves them.
De Vries FFC LXXIII 65ff.; India: Thompson-Balys.
Found mortar taken to king reveals peasant girl‘s wisdom.

Peasant finds mortar in his field and against his
daughter’s advice takes it to the king, who demands the pestle as well. Peasant
laments that he has not followed daughter‘s advice. King summons her. *Type
875; De Vries FFC LXXIII 15ff., 62ff.

King
propounds three riddles to abbot to answer on pain of death. Herdsman disguises
as abbot and answers questions. *Type 922; **Anderson FFC XLII; Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 55; Fb “hyrde” I 719; India: Thompson-Balys; Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.

Witty questions and answers between youth and servant. *BP II 359 n. 2; Fb
“Salomon”; Swiss: Jegerlehner Oberwallis 317 No. 146.

King asks questions; youth returns riddling
answers. *Type 921; **De Vries FFC LXXIII 111ff., 308ff.; Anderson FFC XLII 356
n. 2; Missouri French: Carrière; India: *Thompson-Balys.

King propounds riddles and questions to his clever minister. **De Vries
FFC LXXIII 365ff.; *Encyc. Rel. Ethics s.v. “Ahiqar”; *Marc Studien zur vgl.
Littgesch. II 393f., III 52; **Meissner Das Märchen vom weisen Achikar
(Leipzig, 1917); Jewish: *Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys.
King and peasant vie in riddling questions and answers.
King and peasant: the plucked fowl.

The king gives riddling questions to a peasant, who always
interprets them right. The king says that he will send the peasant a fowl which
he shall pluck. The king gives the same questions to his courtiers, who cannot
interpret them. They pay the peasant good money for the answers. Peasant tells
king that he has plucked the fowl. Anderson FFC XLII 342; India:
Thompson-Balys.

What four things are hardest to hold? Wolf by eyebrows,
bear by claws, snake by tail, hawk by beak.

What are best and worst stones? Best: altar, whetstone,
millstone; worst: hailstone, stone in the eye, gallstone.

Riddle: what is the best fowl?

What is the best fowl? The goose, since it makes the
cabbage sweet and the bed soft.

What is best religion--Christian or Mohammedan? They are
equally good:

as both eyes are equally dear to you, so are both religions to
God. (Cf. †J1262.9.) Anderson FFC XLII 237.
Riddle: what kind of work occupies most men?

What kind of work occupies most men? Healing, for every
sick man practices this.
What is the greatest? A sense of shame.
What is the greatest villainy? Stealing.
What is moistest? The south wind.

(In spite of childbirth pains women continue becoming
pregnant.) Arab: Azov JPASB II 415f.
Riddle: what is the hardest to skin?
What is the hardest to skin? The male member.
Who are the best painters? Women
(in the art of make-up). Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Riddle: what is the best time to eat? For the rich man,
when he wishes; for the poor man, when he has something to eat.
What are the most accursed things?

What are the most accursed things? A thriftless wife, a
baldheaded daughter, a sour-faced daughter-in-law, a crooked axle, and a field
which lies across the village road.

What is the most difficult to find and the most difficult
to lose? The truth.
Who are really irresistible? Meat and drink.
Who are really meek? Cows and daughters.

Which is best, domestic or ascetic life? With good wife
domestic life is best.
Which is the best of flowers? Cotton.
What is most faithful thing in world?
What is most faithless thing in world?

Learned professor from one university examines by signs a

Is town too full of anchorites?

Saint entering holy town is sent cup full to brim of milk
by its worldly-minded fakirs that he may know the town can hold no more

Thompson-Balys.

child:
How far is it from happiness to misfortune? One day;
yesterday I was herdsman and now I am abbot.

content: Riddle: what is softer than swan down?
Riddle: what is harder than stone?

child:
Riddle: how far is it from one end of the earth to the
other (east to west)?

How far is it from one end of the earth to the other? A
day’s journey, since the sun makes it daily.
Riddle: how deep is the earth (or how far to lower world)?

How deep is the earth? It is deep: my grandfather went into
it (died) years ago and has not yet returned.

How deep is the earth? My father went five years ago to
measure it (died); when he returns I shall tell you the result.
Riddle: what is the center of the earth?

Where is the center of the earth? Here; if you don‘t
believe it, measure it yourself.

Where is the center of the earth? Here, for the earth is
round and any point can serve as center.
Riddle: how deep is the sea?
How deep is the sea? A stone’s throw.

How deep is the sea? At first, knee-deep; further on,
waist-deep, neck-deep; and beyond that over the head.

content: Riddle: deaths from sleepiness, anger, and greed.

Elephant sleeps before snake‘s hole. Snake bites elephant
and kills it. Jackal eats hole in elephant and is caught inside. Snake can’t
get out of its hole. India: Thompson-Balys.
Riddle: one killed none and yet killed twelve.

(Horse is poisoned; raven eats of him and dies; twelve
robbers eat raven and die.) *Type 851; BP I 188ff.; *Fb “hest” I 598b, “ravn”

child: Riddle: how far is it from earth to heaven?

*Type 922; BP III 231; Anderson FFC XLII 113; Jewish:
*Neuman.

How far is it from earth to heaven? A day‘s journey, since
Christ went to heaven in one day.

(A half-day’s
journey, similar reason). *Anderson FFC XLII 119; Wesselski Bebel I 36 No. 75.

How far is it from earth to heaven? A day‘s journey, since
there is no inn to stop at on the way.

How far is it from earth to heaven? So and so high, and if
you don’t believe it, measure it yourself.
How far is it from earth to heaven? As far as you can see.

How far is it from earth to heaven? As far as from heaven
to earth.

How far is it from earth to heaven? Not far; when it
thunders there it can be heard here.

How far from earth to heaven? A calf‘s (fox’s) tail, if it
were long enough.

*Anderson FFC XLII 121;
BP III 231; cf. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 96; Fb “kalvehale”.

How far from earth to heaven? A leg‘s length, for it is
written, Heaven is my throne and earth my footstool.

How far from earth to heaven? One step, for they say, He
stands with one foot in the grave and one in heaven.

How far from earth to heaven? The devil knows for he has
fallen this distance.

How wide is heaven? So and so wide, and if you do not
believe it, go measure it yourself.
